description: A lightweight black helmet that provides excellent protection from all sorts of damage.
An all-encompassing black helmet that covers your entire face and neck, providing excellent protection from all sorts of damage with a built-in gas mask air filter.

A snug-fitting custom made full body black synthetic blend jumpsuit, with some slick hidden pockets sewn into its lining. The suit itself is rather protective, and very comfortable in almost all conditions. It even has a single, small magazine pouch sewn into each of its legs. Sneaky.

use_action.holster_msg: You stash your %s in your sneaky leg pocket.

description: A comfortable, but suprisingly tough snug long-sleeved composite material shirt with super-flexible plastic reinforcements at key points to protect the elbows and spine. A bit bulky for a undershirt, but very high quality. Favored by special forces units.

An older style of kevlar helmet that has long fallen out of use in most armed forces. Still, it provides decent protection from pistol-caliber threats and shrapnel to the head, and it's somewhat lighter than more modern protective helmets.

A rather tough, yet lightweight jacket with fewer pockets than heavier coats, made to be comfortable to wear in hot climates and to be comfortably worn beneath armored vests.  Favored by the military, especially during the hot summer months.

This non-modular heavy weight kevlar vest has one rather large pocket and three double-stacked smaller pockets designed to hold some small magazines and a variety of tactical gear, making it an affordable and popular option among law enforcement and private contractors alike. It's heavier and bulkier than a traditional kevlar vest, and cannot be worn beneath clothing easily as a result.

This non-modular vest is noticably bulkier than most kevlar vests owing to its heavier IIIA rated kevlar armor panels. While it's too thick to wear beneath a shirt, it can still be slipped beneath a jacket, or an even heavier vest, if you were that paranoid about getting shot in the apocalypse. It lacks any features such as magazine pouches or storage, however.

This old-school flak jacket is designed primarily to stop fragmentation spalding from AP weaponry hitting vehicle cabins from shredding their occupants. It's heavier than a traditional kevlar vest, and though it's great at protecting against fragmentation, cut wounds and some low-caliber threats, it is not by any means a bulletproof vest.

This old-school flak jacket is designed primarily to stop fragmentation spalding from AP weaponry hitting vehicle cabins from shredding their occupants. It's heavier than a traditional kevlar vest, and though it's great at protecting against fragmentation, cut wounds and some low-caliber threats, it is not by any means a bulletproof vest. This one has some large utility pockets sewn into it, along with two small pouches designed to hold pistol magazines.

This is an incredibly bulky suit of near full upper-body IIIA kevlar armor with flak lining and arm protection, with some large magazine pouches and a small utility pouch. Outdated by military standards, though it was still popular among law enforcement and particularly paranoid milita-makers who ate up surplus from the prior. It provides great ballistic protection for the upper body, but it's quite encumbering.

A clearly older, thinner vest of II kevlar. While it's not as protective as more modern III or IIIA soft vests, it's still suitable for wearing under clothing, and it's lighter too. Popular among independent contractors and paranoid civilians, before the cataclysm.

An incredibly light ballistic protection device which covers only the front and back of the torso, beneath kevlar-lined thin hardened steel plates. It is a lot lighter than traditional steel plate carriers, though less protective, making it once favored by certain special-operations units who never intended to get themselves shot to begin with. It has a couple, rather small, magazine pouches.

An incredibly light ballistic protection device which covers only the front and back of the torso, beneath kevlar-lined superalloy plates. It is much lighter than traditional steel plate carriers, though less protective, making it once favored by certain special-operations units who never intended to get themselves shot to begin with. It has a couple, rather small, magazine pouches.

An incredibly light ballistic protection device which covers only the front and back of the torso, beneath kevlar-lined metal plates. This variation skimps on the hardened steel inserts, and opts instead for lighter plates of unknown material, while maintaining the magazine pouch configuration of more 'mainstream' alternatives.
